post.description:
Acknowledges one or more instances, or occurrences, of alarms, optionally
forcing them clear. Added in version 2 of the `writeAlarmInstances` operation.

requestBody.description: Information about the alarms to acknowledge.

200.description:
Success - Indicates the request to acknowledge was processed successfully. If any
alarms failed to be acknowledged, the included `error` object will contain an
entry in the `innerErrors` array for each failed alarm.

post.description:
Creates or updates an instance, or occurrence, of an alarm based on
the requested transition and the state of the current active alarm
with the given `alarmId`.

requestBody.description:
Information about the alarm to create or update. If an alarm is being
updated, only `alarmId`, `workspace`, and `transition`
are applied.

409.description:
For requests which would result in an update to an existing alarm, this
is returned when the request does not represent a valid transition for
the existing alarm. This can occur when attempting to clear an alarm
which is already clear, or when attempting to set an alarm which is
already set at the given severity level.

parameters.name: instanceId
parameters.description: Unique ID of a particular instance, or occurrence, of an alarm.

parameters.name: instanceId
parameters.description: Unique ID of a particular instance, or occurrence, of an alarm.

post.description:
As of version 4 of the `readAlarmInstances` operation, this
route is deprecated. Instead, use the
`POST /nialarm/v1/query-instances-with-filter` route.



Queries for instances, or occurrences, of alarms. Specifying an empty JSON object
in the request body will result in all alarms in the default workspace being returned.

Queries for instances, or occurrences, of alarms. Specifying an empty JSON object
in the request body will result in all alarms being returned.
Deletes multiple alarm instances by their `instanceId`s.

requestBody.description: Information about the alarms to delete.

200.description:
Partial Success - Indicates the request to delete was processed successfully,
but one or more instances failed to delete. The included error object will
contain an entry in the `innerErrors` array for each failed instance.

204.description: Success - Indicates all requested instances were deleted successfully.

get.description: Returns information about API versions and available operations.
Returns available operations for a single version of the API.

parameters.name: version
parameters.description: The version of the API to retrieve operations.

AcknowledgeByInstanceIdRequest.title: Acknowledge By Instance ID Request

instanceIds.description: The `instanceId`s of the alarms which should be acknowledged.

forceClear.description:
Whether or not the affected alarms should have their `clear`
field set to true.

AcknowledgeByInstanceIdRequest.description: Contains information about the alarms to acknowledge.

AcknowledgeByInstanceIdResponse.title: Acknowledge By Instance ID Response

acknowledged.description: The `instanceId`s of the alarms which were successfully acknowledged.

failed.description:
The `instanceId`s of the alarms which were not acknowledged. See
`error` for why each instance failed to be acknowledged. Reasons include
the instance could not be found, the instance was already acknowledged, or
the caller was not authorized to acknowledge the instance.

AcknowledgeByInstanceIdResponse.description: Contains information about which alarms were acknowledged.

AlarmNote.title: Alarm Note

note.description:
Information about a particular alarm instance, such as a description of the
root cause of the alarm.

createdAt.description: The date and time when the note was created.

user.description: The `userId` of the person who created the note.

AlarmNote.description:
Information about a particular alarm instance, such as a description of the root
cause of the alarm.

AvailableV1Operations.title: Available V1 Operations
AvailableV1Operations.description:
Available operations in the v1 version of the API:


- deleteAlarmInstances: The ability to delete alarm instances.


- readAlarmInstances: The ability to query for alarm instances.


- writeAlarmInstances: The ability to create and modify alarm instances.

CreateAlarmTransition.title: Create Alarm Transition

transitionType.title: Alarm Transition Type
transitionType.description:
Specifies a type of alarm transition:

- CLEAR: The transition corresponds to the clearing of the condition
tracked by the alarm (as in, the condition has moved out of the triggered state
and is no longer in an alarm state).

- SET: The transition corresponds to the condition tracked by the alarm
entering into the triggered, or set state.

occurredAt.description: The date and time when the transition occurred.

severityLevel.description:
The severity of the transition. Valid values for `CLEAR` transitions are [-1, -1].
Valid values for `SET` transitions are [1, infinity]. Note that the SystemLink
Alarm UI only has display strings for `SET` severities in the range [1, 4].

value.description: The value that caused the alarm to transition.

condition.description: A description of the condition associated with the transition.

shortText.description: A short description of the condition.

detailText.description: A detailed description of the condition.
detailText.example: Disk usage on CRIO1 is 95% (higher than the configured threshold of 90%)

keywords.description:
Words or phrases associated with a transition. Useful for attaching metadata to a
transition which could aid in an investigation into an alarm's root cause in the future.

properties.description:
Key-value pair metadata associated with a transition. Useful for attaching additional
metadata to a transition which could aid in an investigation into an alarm's root
cause in the future. Property keys must be between 1 and 255 characters.

CreateAlarmTransition.description:
Contains information about a transition used to create or update an
instance, or occurrence, of an alarm.

CreateOrUpdateAlarmRequest.title: Create or Update Alarm Request

alarmId.description:
A value meant to uniquely identify the particular process or condition
tracked by the alarm. For example, alarms created by a tag rule engine
might have their alarmIds set to the concatenation of the path of the tag
which caused the rule to be triggered and the ID of the rule.

workspace.description:
The ID of the workspace in which to create or update the alarm. When not specified,
the default workspace is used based on the requesting user. Added in version 2 of
the `writeAlarmInstances` operation.

notificationStrategyIds.description:
The IDs of the notification strategies which should be triggered if this request
results in an alarm being created or transitioning to a new highest severity.

createdBy.description:
An identifier for who or what created the alarm. This is usually used to identify the
particular rule engine which requested that the alarm be created.

channel.description: An identifier for the tag or resource associated with the alarm.

resourceType.description: The type of resource associated with the alarm.

displayName.description: Optional display name for the alarm. Display names do not need to be unique.

description.description: Optional description text for the alarm.
description.example: Disk space on tester-1 is high. Disk usage was 95% when this alarm was created.

keywords.description:
Words or phrases associated with the alarm. Alarms can be tagged with keywords to make it easier
to find them with queries.

CreateOrUpdateAlarmRequest.description:
Contains information about the alarm to create or update. If an alarm is
being updated, only `alarmId`, `workspace`, and `transition`
are applied.

CreateOrUpdateAlarmResponse.title: Create or Update Alarm Response

instanceId.description: The ID of the created or modified alarm.

CreateOrUpdateAlarmResponse.description: Contains the result of creating or updating an alarm.

DeleteByInstanceIdPartialSuccess.title: Delete By Instance ID Partial Success

deleted.description: The `instanceId`s of the alarms that were successfully deleted.

failed.description:
The `instanceId`s of the alarms that were not deleted. See
`error` for why each instance failed to delete. Reasons include
the instance could not be found or the caller is not authorized to
delete the instance.

DeleteByInstanceIdPartialSuccess.description: Contains information about which alarms were deleted.

DeleteByInstanceIdRequest.title: Delete By Instance ID Request

instanceIds.description: The `instanceId`s of the alarms which should be deleted.

DeleteByInstanceIdRequest.description: Contains information about the alarms to delete.

HttpAlarm.title: Alarm

instanceId.description: The unique identifier for the instance, or occurrence, of the alarm.

alarmId.description:
A value meant to uniquely identify the particular process or condition
tracked by the alarm. For example, alarms created by a tag rule engine
might have their alarmIds set to the concatenation of the path of the tag
which caused the rule to be triggered and the ID of the rule.

workspace.description: The workspace the alarm belongs to.

active.description:
Whether or not the alarm is active. An active alarm
deserves human or automated attention. Alarms always
begin life with `active=True`. This field will be automatically
set to `false` when the `clear`
and `acknowledged` fields are set to `true`.

clear.description:
When set to `true`, the condition that triggered the alarm
no longer matches the trigger condition. When an alarm is created,
`clear` is initially set to `false`. The creator of the alarm
(typically a rule engine or application element of some sort) may determine
that the trigger condition no longer applies, and may send an update, clearing
the alarm. Clearing the alarm does not deactivate the alarm, unless the alarm
had previously been acknowledged. As long as the alarm is `active=true`,
the alarm may transition from `clear=True`to `clear=False` (or vice versa)
multiple times.

acknowledged.description:
When set to `true`, the alarm has been acknowledged by an
alarm handler, which is typically a human. Alarms always begin life with
`acknowledged=False`. Acknowledging an alarm will not
affect the `active` flag unless `clear` is also `true`.
When `clear` and `acknowledged`/> are `true`, the alarm will become
inactive (`active=False`). This field is automatically reset to `false`
when the alarm's `highestSeverityLevel` field increases.

acknowledgedAt.description:
The date and time when the alarm instance was acknowledged. This field will be cleared
when the alarm's `highestSeverityLevel`> field increases.

acknowledgedBy.description:
The `userId` of the individual who acknowledged the alarm. This field will be
cleared when the alarm's `highestSeverityLevel` field increases.

occurredAt.description: The date and time when the alarm was created/first occurred.

updatedAt.description: The date and time when the alarm was last updated or modified.

createdBy.description:
An identifier for who or what created the alarm. This is usually used to identify the
particular rule engine which requested that the alarm be created.

transitions.description:
A collection of `AlarmTransitions` for the alarm. The service stores the first
transition and the most recent 99 other transitions by default. The configuration
for the service determines the total number of stored transitions per alarm.

transitionOverflowCount.description:
The number of transitions which overflowed the `transitions` field for the alarm.
For example, if the alarm transitioned 250 times, `transitionOverflowCount` is set
to 150 and `transitions` contains the first and most recent 99 transitions. The
configuration for the service determines the total number of stored transitions per alarm.

notificationStrategyIds.description:
The IDs of the notification strategies which will be triggered when the alarm
is first created and when its `highestSeverityLevel` increases.

currentSeverityLevel.description: The current severity level of the alarm.

highestSeverityLevel.description: The highest severity level that the alarm has ever been in.

channel.description: An identifier for the tag or resource associated with the alarm.

condition.description: A description of the condition associated with the alarm.

displayName.description: Optional display name for the alarm. Display names do not need to be unique.

description.description: Optional description text for the alarm.
description.example: Disk space on tester-1 is high. Disk usage was 95% when this alarm was created.

keywords.description:
Words or phrases associated with the alarm. Alarms can be tagged with keywords to make it easier
to find them with queries.

notes.description:
A collection of notes for a given alarm instance. Notes are set by humans to
record information such as the root cause of the alarm.

resourceType.description: The type of resource associated with the alarm.

HttpAlarm.description: An individual instance, or occurrence, of an alarm (an alarm, for short). The lifecycle of an alarm begins the first time it is triggered and ends when it has been both acknowledged and cleared. The service enforces the invariant that there can be at most one `active=True` alarm with the same `alarmId`.

HttpAlarmTransition.title: Alarm Transition

transitionType.title: Alarm Transition Type
transitionType.description:
Specifies a type of alarm transition:

- CLEAR: The transition corresponds to the clearing of the condition
tracked by the alarm (as in, the condition has moved out of the triggered state
and is no longer in an alarm state).

- SET: The transition corresponds to the condition tracked by the alarm
entering into the triggered, or set state.

occurredAt.description: The date and time when the transition occurred.

severityLevel.description:
The severity of the transition. Valid values for `CLEAR` transitions are [-1, -1].
Valid values for `SET` transitions are [1, infinity]. Note that the SystemLink
Alarm UI only has display strings for `SET` severities in the range [1, 4].

value.description: The value that caused the alarm to transition.

condition.description: A description of the condition associated with the transition.

shortText.description: A short description of the condition.

detailText.description: A detailed description of the condition.
detailText.example: Disk usage on CRIO1 is 95% (higher than the configured threshold of 90%)

keywords.description:
Words or phrases associated with a transition. Useful for attaching metadata to a
transition which could aid in an investigation into an alarm's root cause in the future.

properties.description:
Key-value pair metadata associated with a transition. Useful for attaching additional
metadata to a transition which could aid in an investigation into an alarm's root
cause in the future. Property keys must be between 1 and 255 characters.

HttpAlarmTransition.description:
A transition within an instance, or occurrence, of an alarm. Alarm transitions record changes
to an alarm's `clear` field as well as an alarm increasing or decreasing in severity.

message.example: The alarm instance '4afb2ce3741fe11d88838cc9' is already acknowledged.

resourceType.description: Type of resource associated with the error

resourceId.description: Identifier of the resource associated with the error

args.description: Positional argument values for the error code

innerErrors.description: Inner errors when the top-level error represents more than one error

example.name: Skyline.OneOrMoreErrorsOccurred
example.message: One or more errors occurred. See the contained list for details of each error.

innerErrors.name: AlarmInstance.InstanceAlreadyAcknowledged
innerErrors.message: The alarm instance '4afb2ce3741fe11d88838cc9' is already acknowledged.

available.description: Whether the operation is available to the caller (for example, due to permissions).

version.description: The version of the available operation.

Operation.description:
An operation provided by the API. Each route functionality is covered by an operation.
As new functionality is added to an operation, the `version` is incremented.

QueryFilter.title: Query

alarmId.description:
AlarmId query. The service will return alarms whose `alarmId`
fields are equal to the query. This query takes case into account.

description.description:
Description query. The service will return alarms whose `description`
fields contain the description query string. This query does not take
case into account.

displayName.description:
Display name query. The service will return alarms whose `displayName`
fields contain the display name query string. This query does not take
case into account.

active.description:
Active status query. The service will return alarms whose `active`
fields are equal to the query.

clear.description:
Clear status query. The service will return alarms whose `clear`
fields are equal to the query.

acknowledged.description:
Acknowledged status query. The service will return alarms whose `acknowledged`
fields are equal to the query.

acknowledgedAtMin.description:
Acknowledged at minimum date query. The service will return alarms which were
acknowledged between `acknowledgedAtMin` and `acknowledgedAtMax`,
inclusive.

acknowledgedAtMax.description:
Acknowledged at maximum date query. The service will return alarms which were
acknowledged between `acknowledgedAtMin` and `acknowledgedAtMax`,
inclusive.

occurredAtMin.description:
Occurred at minimum date query. The service will return alarms which occurred
between `occurredAtMin` and `occurredAtMax`, inclusive.

occurredAtMax.description:
Occurred at maximum date query. The service will return alarms which occurred
between `occurredAtMin` and `occurredAtMax`, inclusive.

currentSeverityLevelMin.description:
Current severity minimum query. The service will return alarms whose current
severity is between `currentSeverityLevelMin` and
`currentSeverityLevelMax`, inclusive.

currentSeverityLevelMax.description:
Current severity maximum query. The service will return alarms whose current
severity is between `currentSeverityLevelMin` and
`currentSeverityLevelMax`, inclusive.

highestSeverityLevelMin.description:
Highest severity minimum query. The service will return alarms whose highest
severity is between `highestSeverityLevelMin` and
`highestSeverityLevelMax`, inclusive.

highestSeverityLevelMax.description:
Highest severity maximum query. The service will return alarms whose highest
severity is between `highestSeverityLevelMin` and
`highestSeverityLevelMax`, inclusive.

createdBy.description:
Created by query. The service will return alarms whose `createdBy` fields
are equal to the query. This query takes case into account.

channel.description:
Channel query. The service will return alarms whose `channel` fields are
equal to the query. This query takes case into account and supports wildcard
match checking with glob-style wildcards.

resourceType.description:
Resource type query. The service will return alarms whose `resourceType`
fields are equal to the query. This query takes case into account.

properties.description:
Property query. The service will return alarms whose `properties` fields
contain all of the specified key/value pairs. Property keys must be between 1
and 255 characters.

keywords.description:
Keyword query. The service will return alarms whose `keywords` fields
contain all of the specified keywords.

workspaces.description:
Workspace query. The service will return alarms whose `workspace` field
is one of the specified workspaces. By default, only instances in the default
workspace are returned. Specify an array containing a single value of `*`
to query all workspaces. Added in version 3 of the `readAlarmInstances` operation.

QueryFilter.description:
Object describing the fields of an alarm query which can be composed in the query
request's `subQuery` array, enabling multiple queries to be AND'ed together.

QueryRequest.title: Query Request

subQueries.description:
Additional queries. The service will return alarms which match any of the
queries in the `subQueries` array. If a top-level query was provided,
the top-level query will be AND'ed with each of the sub queries.

returnMostRecentlyOccurredOnly.description:
Whether or not the Alarm Service should group the alarms matched
by this query by `alarmId`, and then only return the most recent
alarm for each grouping. In this context, recency is based on when
the alarm occurred, not when it was last updated.

orderBy.description:
How results should be sorted:

- DATE_UPDATED_FORWARD: Results are sorted in ascending order relative to the alarm's `updatedAt` field.

- DATE_UPDATED_BACKWARD: Results are sorted in descending order relative to the alarm's `updatedAt` field.

skip.description:
Number of entries to skip in the response list. Typically used
in combination with the `take` parameter to implement pagination.

take.description:
Number of entries to include in the response list, or 0 to use the default.
The number of alarms returned may be smaller than the specified `take`.
Typically used in combination with the `skip` parameter to
implement pagination.

QueryRequest.description: Contains filter information for querying alarms.

QueryResponse.title: Query Response

totalCount.description: The total number of alarms which matched your query.

filterMatches.description: Array containing the alarms which matched your query.

QueryResponse.description: Contains information about the alarms matched by a query.

QueryWithFilterRequest.title: Query With Filter Request

filter.description:
The alarm query filter in [Dynamic Linq](https://github.com/ni/systemlink-OpenAPI-documents/wiki/Dynamic-Linq-Query-Language).
Allowed properties in the filter are:


- `acknowledged`: Boolean indicating whether or not the alarm was acknowledged


- `acknowledgedAt`: DateTime the alarm was acknowledged


- `active`: Boolean indicating whether or not the alarm is active


- `alarmId`: String value uniquely identifying the process or condition tracked by the alarm


- `channel`: String identifier for the tag or resource associated with the alarm


- `clear`: Boolean indicating whether or not the alarm was cleared


- `createdBy`: String value identifying the user who created the alarm


- `currentSeverityLevel`: Int32 value representing the severity level of the alarm


- `description`: String value describing the alarm


- `displayName`: String value displayed for the alarm


- `highestSeverityLevel`: Int32 value representing the highest severity level of the alarm


- `keywords`: List of string values associated with the alarm


- `occurredAt`: DateTime the alarm was created/first occurred


- `occurredWithin`: TimeSpan in which the alarm was created/first occurred


- `properties`: Dictionary with string keys and values representing alarm metadata


- `resourceType`: String value representing the type of resource associated with the alarm


- `workspace`: String identifiers of the workspace to include in the query


- `workspaceName`: String value name of the workspace the alarm belongs to


            
Allowed constants in the filter are:


- `RelativeTime.CurrentDay`: TimeSpan representing the elapsed time between now and the start of the day


- `RelativeTime.CurrentWeek`: TimeSpan representing the elapsed time between now and the start of the week


- `RelativeTime.CurrentMonth`: TimeSpan representing the elapsed time between now and the start of the month


- `RelativeTime.CurrentYear`: TimeSpan representing the elapsed time between now and the start of the year

substitutions.description:
Makes substitutions in the query filter expression. Substitutions for the query expression are indicated
by non-negative integers that are prefixed with the `@` symbol. Each substitution in the given expression
will be replaced by the element at the corresponding index (zero-based) in this list. For example,
`@0` in the filter expression will be replaced with the element at the zeroth index of the substitutions list.

returnMostRecentlyOccurredOnly.description:
Whether or not the Alarm Service should group the alarms matched
by this query by `alarmId`, and then only return the most recent
alarm for each grouping. In this context, recency is based on when
the alarm occurred, not when it was last updated.

transitionInclusionOption.description:
Determines which transitions to include in the query results, if any:

- NONE: No transitions are included.

- MOST_RECENT_ONLY: The most recent transition is included.

- ALL: All transitions are included.

referenceTime.description:
The date and time to use as the reference point for `RelativeTime` filters, including time zone information.
Defaults to the current time in UTC.

take.description: Limits the returned list to the specified number of results.

orderBy.description:
The sort order of the returned list of alarms. By default, alarms are sorted in ascending order based on the specified value:

- UPDATED_AT: The date and time the alarm was last updated.

orderByDescending.description:
Whether to sort descending instead of ascending. The elements in the list are sorted ascending by default.
If the orderByDescending parameter is specified, the elements in the list are sorted based on its value.
The orderByDescending value must be a boolean string. The elements in the list are sorted ascending if false
and descending if true.

continuationToken.description:
A token which allows the user to resume a query at the next item in the matching results. When
querying, a token will be returned if a query may be continued. To obtain the next page of results,
pass the token to the service on a subsequent request. The service will respond with a new continuation
token. To paginate results, continue sending requests with the newest continuation token provided
by the service, until this value is null.

returnCount.description: Whether to return the total number of alarms that match the provided filter, disregarding the take value.

QueryWithFilterRequest.description: Contains filter information for querying alarms.

QueryWithFilterResponse.title: Query With Filter Response

alarms.description: The list of alarms returned by the query.

totalCount.description: The total number of alarms which matched the query, if requested.

continuationToken.description:
A token which allows the user to resume a query at the next item in the matching results. When
querying, a token will be returned if a query may be continued. To obtain the next page of results,
pass the token to the service on a subsequent request. The service will respond with a new continuation
token. To paginate results, continue sending requests with the newest continuation token provided
by the service, until this value is null.

QueryWithFilterResponse.description: Contains information about the alarms matched by a query.

version.description: The implementation version of the web service.

V1Operations.title: V1 Operations
V1Operations.description: The operations available in the routes provided by the `/v1` HTTP API.

tags.description: Information about API versions and available operations
